title: Capstone Blog Creation
paragraphs:
Today I created this single page blog. In total it took about 10 hours to create, an utlizes Next.js and React to an interactive webpage without the need to make multiple requests to a server hosted on an AWS instance running Ubuntu 18.04.  React is a javascript front-end framework used to make creating interactive content online simple and modular. The blog selection bar, and blog content is pulled from a JSON file on the server, that is to be manually updated when I make a new blog post. The choice to program my own blog instead of using a service like wordpress is to exmplify my front-end development ability. My capstone project is going to involve all facets of full-stack development, including data retrieve and organization scripts, databases, RESTful API back-end technologies, and front-end development frameworks such as React.
All images in this blog will be at the bottom of the blog post. They are all clickable such that they can be viewed in a lightbox. The blogs will be added on the left side of the page as I progress through my capstone project. This website is not made to be mobile-oreiented.

title: Database and Python Script Created
paragraphs:
This week I developed a Python script that downloads, reads, and parses the .pdf files found at any given location. The script uses BeautifulSoup, Pandas, Numpy, and a vareity of other packages. The pdf file locations are discovered using a regular expression that finds .pdf urls in html. Those urls are then downloaded directly and saved to a directory. A package called Tabula pareses the downloaded PDF files for tables and converts them into dataframes that are readable by Pandas. The dataframes are then seperated into columns of data. The columns are searched for a readable date such as “12-Jan” and that is converted to a Python datetime readable format.
 The columns that contain the menu items are then organized by date and sent to a seperate method that uploads them to a MySql Database. The MySql database is hosted on AWS RDS and is designed in Third Normal Form. Below there is an Entity Relationship Diagram, as well as a Logical Model of the Database.

title: Python Script Improved, Node.js RESTful API Created
paragraphs:
For week 3, I worked on debugging the python script I wrote last week, as well as beginning the NPM project for the Node.js REST API that will be responsible for serving the SQL data of the menus. The client will access the data through a url such a joelaustin.net/menu/2019-02-23?type=0. This url would indicate that the user wants the menu from the date specficied as a GET request to a directory, and has a query string that contains the type of the menu, 1 or 0, correlating to lunch or dinner. 
 My python script had a few bugs that involved dates and a change in month. The script was incorrectly setup to not handle months that were 31 days long. This issue has now been fixed. I also improved logging on the python script so now it looks very presentable.

title: HTTPS on Restful API, Google Stuffs
paragraphs: For week 4, I span up a new AWS instance to use for my Restful API that facilitates the transfer of data between end clients and the backend database. I also explored the feasibility of getting the Google assistant to read out menus for specified dates. This is why I immediately setup HTTPS on then new server. Google Dialogflow, which is Google’s service for creating assistant actions, has a feature called “Dialogflow Fulfillment” and has an open source library that is used to create “fulfillment services”. I used this library to create a Webhook that returns a Javascript Promise with the information that is required. The promise also returns a SSML string. SSML stands for Synthesized Speech Markup Language, and is used to process things that make speech more natural like pauses and acronym readings.

title: Google Assistant Working
paragraphs: This week, I finished getting the Google Assistant working with my Restful API. Currently, If someone posts to “api.joelaustin.net/google” with a response in Dialogflow formatting that contains a date and a menutype for parameters, they will receive back a SSML speech response that reads the menu aloud. This is done as my fulfillment for my “Get Menu” action in “Actions on Google”.
